author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Anton Troianovski
title: Artillery Exchanges in Eastern Ukraine May Presage Invasion, U.S. Warns
description: As shelling intensified in the east, officials warned that Moscow might use false claims of “genocide” against Russians in the region as a pretext for an attack.
content: STANYTSIA LUHANSKA, Ukraine — Residents near Ukraine’s front line rushed into basements for cover Thursday as exchanges of artillery fire with Russian-backed separatists reached their most intense level in months, an ominous development amid Western fears that Russia might use the fighting as a pretext to invade Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Moity
title: Covering the U.S. During the Pandemic
description: Reporters on The Times’s National desk share how, for more than two years, they have covered a country navigating Covid-19.
content: It has been nearly two years since the first Covid cases were reported in the United States. Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, the National desk has been covering the immense changes occurring in every part of the country. Reporters on the desk, stationed across the nation, are continuously adapting to major events while simultaneously dealing with the risks of Covid-19 themselves. Below, some of those reporters share a few of the ways they have adapted to this new reality — and what they’ve learned along the way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Must I Keep Reminding My Adult Son About Family Birthdays?
description: A mother who has always nudged her youngest about sending cards and gifts wonders what her responsibility is now that he’s older and married.
content: I have three grown sons, all married with children. The wives of the older two meticulously observe every family birthday and milestone event with cards and gifts. My youngest son didn’t marry until his mid-30s. While single, he often neglected these occasions. I would remind him about them, particularly for his young nieces and nephews, but he was spotty about acknowledging them. And I heard frequently from my daughters-in-law about hurt feelings. Now that he’s married, I had hoped his wife would take up the cause of cards and gifts for family unity. She hasn’t. And my other daughters-in-law still let me know about every omission. What more should I do?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Languedoc Reds: Still Searching for an Identity
description: For this region, once known for its vast output of inexpensive wines, the journey toward recognition has been long and winding. Is a destination any closer?
content: Not so long ago, the Languedoc region was often called “the California of France.” Not so much because it’s hot, dry and vast, though all are true, but because as far as wine was concerned, anything goes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Film Club: ‘The Joy of Cooking (Insects)’
description: Would you eat bugs for a better environment?
content: What’s your favorite food? Pizza? French fries? Ice cream? How about grasshoppers,  crickets or termites?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A City Ballet Star Bids Farewell to the ‘Crazy Ballerina Life’
description: After 22 years, Teresa Reichlen, a “low-key” Hitchcock blonde, steps into her next chapter: motherhood and running a gallery.
content: New York City Ballet’s fall season came and went, and if Teresa Reichlen was being honest with herself, she wasn’t feeling it. This was concerning. What kind of dancer wasn’t itching to perform after 18 months off the stage?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks, Champion of Indigenous Peoples, Dies at 85
description: As a teenager, she was the star of a film about an Aboriginal girl raised by a white family. As an adult, she fought discrimination in Australia against her people.
content: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks, who as a teenager was believed to be the first female Indigenous person to star in a feature film in Australia and later became an Aboriginal rights activist, died on Jan. 26 in Alice Springs, in Australia’s Northern Territory. She was 85 and had been living in Utopia, an Aboriginal homeland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Strawberry Mansion’ Review: Adventures in Slumberland
description: A taxman lives in a future world that evokes the disarray of dream logic in this creative and surreal sci-fi movie.
content: “Strawberry Mansion,” a soulful sci-fi oddity from Albert Birney and Kentucker Audley, is a dollhouse constructed on a fault line. Birney and Audley, who both directed and edited the film, evoke the disarray of dream logic: The sets shift, the sound effects heighten and the props grow and shrink. Initially, the style is stifling, giving the sense that the wallpaper might matter more than the plot. One room is painted solid pink, with matching pink house plants and a pink broom. Another room houses a machine covered in incomprehensible widgets and tubes, plus a turtle named Sugar Baby. But oh, how the two filmmakers enjoy knocking down the walls of their own creation. This is a movie about letting the mind roam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Looking Straight at the Struggles of Old Age
description: In two Paris theater productions, there’s no sugarcoating the physical decline that comes at the end of a long life.
content: PARIS — There is something piercing, almost brutal, about watching someone struggle to walk, eat or even sit down. When faced with the physical decline that often comes with old age, many of us instinctively avert our eyes. In Paris, however, two theater artists are forcing audiences to look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Shiffrin’s Olympics End as They Began, With a Sudden Fall and a Frank Review
description: A disqualification in the combined meant the American star failed to win an individual medal in Beijing. At times, the experience turned into a public catharsis.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Queer Indigenous Artists Reclaiming a Fluid Sense of Gender
description: Colonialist conceptions of gender have long sought to erase more expansive views. But a new generation is making work that honors their cultures’ beliefs on their own terms.
content: THE PHOTOGRAPH FRAMES what appears to be a female figure, naked and glossed with oil, against a backdrop of pale rose brown, just a shade darker than the model’s skin. Long, dark hair cascades over the breasts and, where the viewer might expect the genitalia to be, the model grips the great rack of a caribou, the skull cupped like a codpiece and the antlers jutting out, beams spread nearly four feet wide and reaching in height from mid-thigh to the tip of the model’s nose, with 15 points on each side.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Our nonfiction recommendations this week take you from medieval manuscripts to Covid-era domestic arrangements; and from the birth of American transcendentalism in Concord, Mass., to the death of a latter-day American transcendentalist in the Parvati Valley of northern India. We also recommend a book that explores English’s role as the world’s dominant language and, in fiction, new novels by Julie Otsuka, Sarah Manguso, Paul Vidich and more. Happy reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Australia gives a green light to Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine for children aged 6 to 11.
description: The country is the first to grant provisional authority for the Moderna vaccine to be used in children younger than 12.
content: Australia’s medicines regulator granted provisional approval on Wednesday to Moderna’s coronavirus vaccine in children aged 6 to 11. It is the first time a national regulator has approved the vaccine for children younger than 12.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Broadcast coverage on Thursday includes skiing, curling and figure skating.
description: Eileen Gu, the California freestyle skier competing for China, seeks her third medal, this time in the women’s halfpipe final.
content: The U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games continues on Thursday with medals in skiing, speedskating and figure skating up for grabs. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Julia Fox, Eric Adams and the Return of the Suit
description: Here’s what I saw at New York Fashion Week.
content: It’s been a while since a New York Fashion Week show was an hour late and almost no one cared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris and Maggie Astor
title: Vulnerable to the Virus, High-Risk Americans Feel Pain as the U.S. Moves On
description: Transplant recipients, cancer patients and millions of other Americans with risk factors feel ignored and abandoned as their neighbors, and their government, seek a return to normal.
content: Denisse Takes’s world is very small these days. She makes a living by producing songs from her living room, plays “Animal Crossing” online with friends and leaves her home in Burbank, Calif., only occasionally to walk her dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Corkery
title: Walmart profits grow as consumers continue to spend.
description: The retailer said total revenue rose to $153 billion in its most recent quarter, up 0.5 percent from a year earlier.
content: Walmart navigated rising inflation and fickle consumer confidence in its fourth quarter, as sales rose and profit increased, beating analysts’ expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Dr. Herbert Benson, Who Saw the Mind as Medicinal, Dies at 86
description: A cardiologist and best-selling author, he was initially a skeptic before finding that a person can influence bodily health through meditation.
content: Herbert Benson, a Harvard-trained cardiologist whose research showing the power of mind over body helped move meditation into the mainstream, died on Feb. 3 at a hospital in Boston. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Sam Waterston Is Still the Face of ‘Law & Order’
description: The actor originally signed on for only one season as Jack McCoy but became synonymous with the series, which returns Feb. 24. “It’s nice to come back and just witness the thing we made,” he said.
content: “Law & Order” premiered on NBC in 1990. A procedural that was really two procedurals conjoined, the first half of each episode focused on the investigation of a crime, the second on the prosecution of the accused. Among the original cast members was Michael Moriarty, who played an assistant district attorney. During the fourth season, under clouded circumstances, Moriarty left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: The Paradox of the Lizard Tail, Solved
description: It can break off in an instant but also stay firmly attached. Scientists have figured out the microscopic structures that make this survival skill possible.
content: When choosing between life and limb, many animals willingly sacrifice the limb. The ability to drop appendages is known as autotomy, or self-amputation. When backed into a corner, spiders let go of legs, crabs drop claws and some small rodents shed clumps of skin. Some sea slugs will even decapitate themselves to rid themselves of their parasite-infested bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. adds WeChat and AliExpress to a list of notorious piracy markets.
description: The Biden administration added several major Chinese businesses to a list of counterfeiters, but removed any mention of Amazon’s foreign operations.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday added WeChat’s e-commerce ecosystem and AliExpress, an e-commerce site owned by Alibaba, to an annual list of markets that the United States says engage in counterfeiting and copyright violations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Justice Department Sues Missouri Over Expansive Gun-Rights Law
description: Attorney General Merrick Garland argued that the law allowing citizens to sue police for $50,000 for violating their right to bear arms was unconstitutional.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sued Missouri on Wednesday over the state’s far-reaching gun law, which discourages local officials from enforcing federal firearms measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins and Troy Closson
title: 4-Year-Old and His Grandmother Were Killed by Poison, Police Say
description: There have been no arrests in the case, the police said, but the deaths of Wilhelm Ducatl and Tofoon Man are being investigated as homicides.
content: When a 4-year-old boy, Wilhelm Ducatl, died of a strange stomach illness in Brooklyn last May, it appeared he had tragically passed of natural causes. But when a doctor conducted a post-mortem examination, he discovered a strange rash on the boy and ordered a toxicology exam.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a three-bedroom house in White Plains, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Hopewell, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Given a Chance at a Mediocre Season, the Celtics Said: We’ll Pass
description: Ime Udoka, the team’s first-year coach, has convinced his players that sharing the ball is the key to a potent offense. Now the Celtics are climbing in the standings.
content: BOSTON — Ime Udoka has been emphasizing ball movement since the day the Celtics hired him as their coach. At his introductory news conference last June, Udoka apologized to Brad Stevens, his predecessor and the team’s newly appointed president of basketball operations, as a way of softening the blow before he pointed out that the Celtics had ranked near the bottom of the league in assists last season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Another Booster? Not Yet
description: Federal health officials say they are not planning on recommending fourth doses any time soon.
content: Protection from Covid vaccine boosters might be shorter than we would have hoped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Announces Raft of Changes Meant to Deter Cyberthreats
description: The moves came a week after the department made its largest financial seizure ever, confiscating over $3.6 billion worth of Bitcoin stolen in a 2016 hacking.
content: WASHINGTON — A top Justice Department official said on Thursday that the agency was bolstering its efforts to address cybercrime, as cryptocurrencies have increasingly become part of the global economy and cyberthreats become more and more common.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Handshakes and hugs have some Canadians questioning law enforcement’s soft touch with the protests.
description: Images on social media contrast the response to the truckers with heavy-handed action last year against Indigenous people who blocked logging.
content: Police in Ottawa are poised for a crackdown on the protests that have immobilized Canada’s capital, but after three weeks of scant enforcement, images of police officers fraternizing with protesters have some Canadians questioning the gentle treatment of the demonstrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends checking out a short-form divorce dramedy, a dreamy show about artistry and a gentle auteur comedy.
content: ‘State of the Union’When to watch: Now, on SundanceNow and AMC+.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘A Banquet’ Review: Starving for a Higher Purpose
description: A family of grieving women is thrown once more into chaos when the eldest daughter refuses to eat, saying she must do so by divine decree.
content: When it gets down to it, demonic haunting bears striking similarities to divine possession. So who gets canonized and who receives an exorcism? “A Banquet,” the first feature film from the director Ruth Paxton, smartly asks audiences to consider the overlaps between reality and fantasy, psychosis and evangelism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: San Francisco ousters
description: Why are liberal candidates losing in liberal cities?
content: Elections to the San Francisco Board of Education are not normally national bellwethers. The city is a proud symbol of liberalism, not a swing district, and school-board elections — as Thomas Fuller, The Times’s San Francisco bureau chief, notes — “have for decades been obscure sideshows to the more high-profile political contests.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Hochul Is the Star as Democrats Gather for a Cuomo-Free Convention
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul received the Democratic nomination for governor on Thursday, as she seeks her first full term after succeeding Andrew Cuomo.
content: Six months after Kathy Hochul suddenly became New York’s first female governor, the Democratic State Convention on Thursday showcased just how much the political dynamics of the state had changed since Andrew M. Cuomo’s stunning resignation, as Ms. Hochul easily secured her party’s endorsement in her race for a full term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Want a Profitable Short-Term Rental? Try These Spots.
description: A performance analysis by AirDNA isolates the best places to invest.
content: For those fortunate enough to own an Airbnb or Vrbo property, 2021 was a stellar year. According to a new analysis by AirDNA, an unaffiliated company that collects and analyzes data from short-term rental listings, 62 percent of such properties were occupied at any given time in 2021 — up 5 percent from 2020 and 10 percent from 2019. And thanks to the increased demand, landlords were able to charge higher rates, earning them an average of 39 percent more annually than before the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 17, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Feb. 17, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about challenges faced by U.S. intelligence agencies in deciphering the moves of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia described incorrectly John Sipher’s role with the C.I.A. in Moscow. He served there as a C.I.A. officer, not as the station chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: What Would It Mean to End the Covid State of Emergency?
description: A new politics of pandemic resignation is setting in, but what it would look like to “get on with our lives,” and how to do so, remains unclear.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ada Petriczko
title: Philadelphia drops its vaccine mandate for indoor dining.
description: The city introduced a new system of Covid-19 response that is tied to specific pandemic metrics and could change as the situation evolves.
content: Philadelphia is joining a growing list of cities that will no longer require proof of vaccination to enter places that serve food or drink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: His Conducting Wasn’t Always Pleasant. But It Was the Truth.
description: Michael Gielen’s precise, intellectually charged work made him one of the most stimulating maestros of the 20th century. Now a set of 88 CDs offers the deepest insight yet.
content: Read the reviews that the German conductor Michael Gielen received during his career, and you find a running theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Dog’ Review: Man and Beast Hit the Road
description: In his directing debut, Channing Tatum plays an Army Ranger on a healing journey with a canine comrade.
content: Road comedies that pair an animal and a movie star are a minor genre unto themselves. The best examples, in my opinion, involve Clint Eastwood and an orangutan named Clyde, though the recent one with Eastwood and a rooster wasn’t bad. Channing Tatum is a different kind of screen presence — sweeter, chattier, bulkier — and in “Dog,” which he directed with Reid Carolin, he amiably shares the screen with (spoiler alert!) a dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Nicholas Kristof Can’t Run for Governor in Oregon After Losing Appeal
description: The State Supreme Court rejected Mr. Kristof’s bid to appear on the ballot, agreeing with officials that he did not meet the state’s three-year residency requirement.
content: Nicholas Kristof, a former New York Times columnist who left the newspaper to run for governor of Oregon, does not qualify to appear on the ballot this year, the state’s Supreme Court ruled on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: After 30 Years of Peace, Ukraine Crisis Shakes Europeans
description: The happy complacency of post-Cold War peace is being shattered by Russia’s threats, demands and massive military buildup around Ukraine.
content: BRUSSELS — Ulrike Franke is a self-confessed German millennial, a defense analyst who worries about her generation’s allergy to the military, especially as it moves into positions of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: After an Unexpected Rise, Hochul Cements Her Front-Runner Status
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul, who will become the state Democrats’ standard-bearer today, was not a sure bet when she replaced Andrew Cuomo last summer.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at how Gov. Kathy Hochul assembled a campaign juggernaut. We’ll also look at the difficulties facing would-be small business owners who dream of becoming marijuana retailers in New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa and Richard Fausset
title: Prosecutors Show Voluminous Evidence of Racism by Arbery Murderers
description: The government emphasized not only racial slurs but also expressions of support for vigilantism.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — Federal prosecutors in the hate crimes trial of Ahmaud Arbery’s three murderers on Wednesday presented the jury with voluminous digital evidence of racism, as the government continued to build its case that the defendants, who are white, chased Mr. Arbery through their South Georgia neighborhood because he was Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Sandra Naeslund of Sweden takes the gold in the ski cross final.
description: In the event, four skiers burst out of the start house at the same time and race down the course all at once.
content: For all of its high speed and spills, Alpine skiing is, in its own way, a controlled, stately affair. After all, each skier gets a fair chance to race down the mountain, uninterrupted and unmolested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Downfall: The Case Against Boeing’ Review: Behind Two Fatal Crashes
description: This documentary on Netflix leaves the impression that the 737 Max’s entire existence is rotten.
content: Regardless of any changes that Boeing made to the 737 Max, regardless of the clearance the revised plane received from the Federal Aviation Administration in late 2020, “Downfall: The Case Against Boeing” leaves the impression that its entire existence is a mistake: that it was cobbled together for the wrong reasons, to boost short-term stock gains and to avoid the time and costs of engineering a new, non-737 plane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘The Automat’ Review: Put a Nickel in the Slot for Nostalgia
description: A documentary about Horn & Hardart’s automated cafeterias is sweet and shaggy, but an engrossing tale of cultural harmony.
content: Whatever nostalgia is — homesickness, fantasy, delusion — it’s flooding “The Automat.” There’s something about people’s memories of these automated cafeterias that flourished in the United States for much of the 20th century — you put a nickel into a slot, open a door in an enormous wall of cabinets and pull out, say, a slice of pie or a ham sandwich — that sends them back to the era in which they frequented one. The documentary Lisa Hurwitz has directed about Automats is shaggy and full of cutesy stuff, mostly involving Mel Brooks. But the sight of all these lit-up faces — see Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Carl Reiner, Colin Powell — made me hunger to be back where they wish they were: at 5, at 17, at 20-something, plunked down at a table with a bowl of baked beans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Inspector Ike’ Review: A Murder Mystery Send-Up, ’70s-TV style
description: This microbudget comedy, an affectionate parody of old-time television “mystery movies,” is an often-inspired goof.
content: Cinephiles tend to associate American microbudget filmmaking with raw, edgy earnestness, but some aspirational indies are very much into knowingly silly comedy — see, for instance, the 2017 short “Snowy Bing Bongs Across the North Star Combat Zone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: A Parasitic Wasp Unmasked: One Species Is Actually 16 Species
description: The tiny, iridescent parasitoid wasp is the latest insect shown to be a cryptic complex of genetically distinct species.
content: The tiny, iridescent Ormyrus labotus always seemed suspicious for a parasitoid wasp. It wasn’t the wasp’s striking beauty — wasps can be conventionally attractive, too — but its life strategy. Parasitoid wasps lay their eggs on or inside other insects and arthropods, and the larvae eat their way out when they hatch. Each parasitoid wasp species tends to prefer one or a few hosts. But Ormyrus labotus had been observed laying its eggs in more than 65 different species of insects — far more than one or a few.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: Biden Keeps Blaming the Supply Chain for Inflation. That’s Dishonest.
description: Our supply problems are the product of an overstimulated economy, not the cause of it.
content: In an interview with Lester Holt of NBC last week, President Biden hewed closely to his talking points on inflation, which over the past 12 months has risen at its fastest rate in 40 years. “The reason for the inflation is the supply chains were cut off,” he insisted, as he has done several times before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Two Teenagers Were Fighting. Only the Black One Was Handcuffed.
description: A video of the fight at a New Jersey mall circulated widely online. Gov. Philip D. Murphy said the appearance of “racially disparate treatment” was “deeply, deeply disturbing.”
content: It was a routine scuffle that normally would have gotten little attention: two teenagers taking swings at each other in a New Jersey mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Half of the cars arriving at dealers are already sold, AutoNation says.
description: The automotive retailer said tight demand and limited supply, driven by shortages in computer chips, is likely to continue well into the year.
content: The tight supplies of new and used cars that have damped auto sales and pushed prices higher have not eased and are likely to linger well into this year, according to AutoNation, the country’s largest automotive retailer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Art-Filled Hotel Inside a Former Wall Street Trading Hub
description: Plus: a Brooklyn design destination, a new Niki de Saint Phalle biography and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Labor groups urge Justice Dept. to ramp up prosecutions of unruly passengers.
description: A letter to Attorney General Merrick Garland cited an upswing in violent behavior against airline and airport workers.
content: A coalition of labor unions representing tens of thousands of airline industry workers urged the Justice Department to step up its prosecutions of unruly passengers on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Florida Girl Arrested Over Threats She Didn’t Make Sues Her School
description: Nia Whims, 13, was held in juvenile detention for 11 days after a classmate impersonated her on Instagram. Information proving her innocence was “available at the press of a button,” a lawsuit claims.
content: The family of a Florida girl who was held in a juvenile-detention center for 11 days after a classmate impersonated her on social media to make threats against their school has filed a lawsuit against the school and Instagram for their roles in the episode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: Faith Ringgold’s Path of Maximum Resistance
description: A survey of her trailblazing, 40-year career in Manhattan shows us how, as a Black artist, she survived and thrived.
content: If you want to catch the heat of the lava flow that was United States racial politics in the 1960s, the second floor of the New Museum in Manhattan is a good place to go. There you’ll find the earliest work in “Faith Ringgold: American People,” the first local retrospective of the Harlem-born artist in almost 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia May Invade in ‘Coming Days,’ U.S. Warns
description: Shelling in eastern Ukraine raises fears of an escalation.
content: Despite Russia’s insistence that it is withdrawing troops from the border with Ukraine, U.S. officials warned that an invasion was imminent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Trahan Martinez and Benjamin Hoffman
title: Eric Kay Found Guilty for His Role in Death of Tyler Skaggs
description: Kay, a former Angels employee, faces decades in prison for providing an Angels pitcher with the fentanyl that led to his death.
content: FORT WORTH — Eric Kay, a former communications director for the Los Angeles Angels, was found guilty on both charges for his role in the death of pitcher Tyler Skaggs in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Leslie Parnas, Celebrated Cellist and Musical Diplomat, Dies at 90
description: His success at a competition in Moscow in 1962 earned him global renown and gave him a platform as a musical emissary.
content: Leslie Parnas, a renowned cellist and teacher whose second-place award at the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow at the height of the Cold War helped propel him to a storied career, died on Feb. 1 at a rehabilitation facility in Venice, Fla. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Regulators open an investigation into ‘phantom braking’ by Teslas.
description: Some drivers have complained that cars using the company’s Autopilot system have been slowing down suddenly even when there are no hazards ahead.
content: The federal government’s main auto-safety regulator has opened a preliminary investigation into sudden braking by Tesla cars equipped with an advanced driver-assistance system that the company calls Autopilot.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As Russian Wins Mount, So Does the Scrutiny
description: The fallout from a doping scandal at the 2014 Sochi Games and a troop buildup on the Ukrainian border have kept Russia, and its athletes, under a microscope.
content: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s Berry Tasty!
description: To celebrate his New York Times debut, Aaron M. Rosenberg throws a little party, and you’re invited.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Thursday puzzles are my favorites because of their intrinsic element of surprise, that extra layer of mystery to dig into. Today’s Aaron M. Rosenberg special, his first crossword for The New York Times, has a cherry of narrative whimsy on top. There’s a scientist with a new invention to show off, and we are all guests at a party, or guinea pigs, if you will. We can mix and mingle and fill in the blanks; we can dine and we will leave, if not sated then quite satisfied.

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: The Best-Seller List Is a Smorgasbord
description: This week’s latest top sellers include unexpected treats and old favorites.
content: ORIGINAL KIN In the vibrant potluck that is the best-seller list, occasionally we find a book that stands out among the usual bowls of chili, trays of baked ziti and platters of Rice Krispie treats. This week the dish that isn’t quite like the others — thriller, mystery, memoir or biography, and so forth — is Jennifer Raff’s “Origin,” which our reviewer described as a “masterly retelling of the story of how, and when, people reached the Americas.” Raff, an anthropological geneticist at the University of Kansas, writes in her introduction, “Looking at the genetic evidence, we will examine the ways in which DNA has challenged and changed our understanding of Native American history, with a special focus on the events that are only indirectly understandable with the archaeological record.” Her approach will be accessible to the pickiest readers, layering personal anecdotes with a visit to a gene-sequencing lab, heavy on compassion and light on jargon. A Goodreads reviewer put it like this about Raff: “As a young mother she can’t help but impart some poignancy in her accounts of those burial sites where toddlers are interred. In doing so she highlights — as she does throughout the book — the humanity of the person whose remains are the subject of research.” “Origin” is Raff’s first book, and it lands on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8.

content: After years of struggling to make payments that hardly put a dent in the loans she took out to attend a now defunct arts school, Victoria Linssen saw a glimmer of hope. content: The Supreme Court has agreed to hear two cases, one involving Harvard and the other the University of North Carolina, that could reshape college admissions. In the coming year, the court will examine whether it’s lawful for college admissions offices to consider a student’s race.

content: At least give Sony credit for recycling. That is the best that can be said for its nitwit treasure-hunt movie “Uncharted,” an amalgam of clichés that were already past their sell-by date when Nicolas Cage plundered the box office in Disney’s “National Treasure” series. Now, it is Tom Holland’s turn to cash in with a musty story about ancient loot, old maps, lost ships, invisible ink and a wealthy scoundrel with disposable minions. But while he’s following in Cage’s inimitable footsteps, Holland also seems in training to become Tom Cruise 2.0.

content: Two senators from opposite sides of the aisle introduced sweeping legislation yesterday that would require online platforms to help parents better control their children’s online experience. content: In 1996, Manuel Miranda, a second-generation Filipino American from Kent, Wash., graduated from Evergreen State College. content: When I was growing up, my dad cooked us massive quantities of basic crepes on Sunday mornings and set the table with butter, jams, plastic squeeze-its of lemon juice, Nutella, cut fruit, you name it. I’d roll mine up with sugar and lemon juice in such excess, it immediately seeped through the pancake and onto my fingertips.

description: The pullout came after a falling out between France and Mali, in West Africa, ending a military effort that failed to drive out violent extremists.
content: PARIS — France announced on Thursday that it would pull out its troops from the West African nation of Mali, bringing to a bitter end a nine-year military mission that has failed to quash a terrorist threat in the increasingly unstable region and has undermined France’s once dominant standing in many of its former African colonies.

author: By Joyelle McSweeney and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Kingdom
description: A poem that’s a spiteful elegy against the indifference surrounding a death.
content: Joyelle McSweeney’s book explores the ecstasy of impending childbirth and the fissure of joy when the baby is born with a birth defect, lives for 13 days and dies. “Kingdom” is a poem written after the baby’s death. It’s a spiteful elegy against the persistent onslaught of spring and of the indifference of the world surrounding a death. This poem’s brilliance (and wounds) register through language’s sonic playfulness, as if to say that language is the only way to clap back at grief. The speaker’s bold agency is empowering — even the last line is an unexpected imperative.Selected by Victoria Chang

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: What Happens When Angry Asian American Parents Get Organized
description: Does the Bay Area school board vote represent fury at Covid closures or something else?
content: Our anxiety over the upcoming midterm and presidential elections has turned every vote, however local and peculiar, into a referendum on the future of the nation. Take last November’s governor’s race in Virginia. After the results came in for the Republican, Glenn Youngkin, hundreds of column inches were dedicated to how the result reflected a growing discontent among normally liberal voters about Covid school closures and critical race theory being taught in schools. This may have been the story of that particular election, but so many people seemed convinced that it was conclusive proof that Democrats had turned against their own party for good and would be summarily be sweeping progressives out of office in 2022 and 2024.

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Rokia Koné, From Mali, Sings for the World. Especially Women.
description: Her international debut album, “Bamanan,” enlists an Irish producer, Jacknife Lee, for songs infused with African history and feminism.
content: African musicians don’t need outside help. Lately, Nigerian Afrobeats, South African amapiano and other sleek, high-tech, thoroughly danceable styles have reached listeners worldwide without Western mediators. But the proof of a collaboration is in its sound, not its pedigree, and the album “Bamanan” is a transcontinental alliance that finds its own synergy.

title: Why Some Red States Aren’t Going for Broke on Abortion — Yet
description: A recent rash of 15-week abortion bans gives us a glimpse of post-Roe America.
content: In 2019 a wave of anti-abortion laws swept this country — a common enough event in the United States, where hundreds of such laws have passed during the last decade. But these grabbed the public’s attention in a way many others hadn’t. Georgia banned abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy, or about two weeks after a missed menstrual period. Ohio, Mississippi, Louisiana and Kentucky did the same, while Missouri banned the procedure at eight weeks. Alabama went the furthest, banning virtually all abortions in the state.

Funerals for friends and family in their 20s, 30s, 40s and 50s continued unabated, and many of us at risk for getting sick had given up hope of a normal life. author: By Nancy Hass
title: A Ring That Encapsulates Chanel No. 5 in Gem Form
description: The warm golden hue and floral notes that define the house’s most iconic fragrance inspired this bloom-like statement piece.
content: When Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel decided in 1920 to branch out from fashion to fragrance, she chose the fifth sample presented by her team of noses, a mélange of ylang-ylang from Madagascar, May rose and piquant jasmine grown in the southern French commune of Grasse. The golden color of Chanel No. 5, which could be seen through the simple square-corner glass bottle — designed to contrast with the ornate cut crystal vessels made by Lalique and Baccarat at the time — was almost as important as its bouquet. That warm yellow hue and the dizzying waft of sillage in its wake were among the things that inspired Patrice Leguéreau, who directs the house’s fine jewelry studio, to render the radically modern scent in gem form. Resembling a flower exploding into bloom with a five-carat emerald-cut diamond as its luminous pistil and stamen, surrounded by a cascade of yellow sapphires and orange spessartite garnets, this captivating ring manages the impossible: turning the fleeting frisson of fragrance into an eternal object of desire.
